content:
AUSTRALIA

BHP (BHP AT) - Co. is said to be mulling options to divest stakes in thermal coal market. (Newswires)

Elders (ELD AT) - Co. is said to eye PGG Wrightson as a potential target in New Zealand. (The Australian)

Galaxy Resources (GXY AT) - Co. Q2 Mt. Cattlin lithium output 56.5K tons vs. guidance 45K-50K tons. (Newswires)

Hub24 (HUB AT) - Co. Q4 net inflows increased by 32.4% Y/Y to AUD 979mln. (Newswires)

Medibank (MPL AT) - Co. is thought to be a possible takeover target for UnitedHealth (UNH). (Newswires)

Rio Tinto (RIO AT) - Co. Q2 Pilbara iron ore output 79.7mln tons vs. Prev. 85.5mln tons Y/Y, Q2 Pilbara iron ore shipments at 85.4mln tons vs. Prev. 88.5mln tons Y/Y, Co. Q2 aluminium output 803k tons vs. Prev. 858k tons Y/Y, while it announces completion of sale in Rossing uranium mine and raises CAPEX for Oyu Tolgoi project to between USD 6.5bln-7.2bln from USD 5.3bln. (Newswires)

Energy - WTI crude futures fell around 1% to below USD 60/bbl. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Japan Display (6740 JT) - Co. is reportedly to spin off smartphone panels unit to raise funds. (Newswires)

Japan Post Insurance (7181 JT) - Co. will refrain from insurance sales until August due to mis-selling policies. (Nikkei)

Yamato Holdings (9064 JT) - Co. is expected to post oper. loss of around JPY 6.0bln vs. Prev. profit JPY 9.6bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Trade - Seoul warned Japan faces 'greater damage' from export curbs and refuted Tokyo’s allegation of banned materials reaching Pyongyang from South Korea, while South Korean Foreign Ministry official said US has indicated it is willing to play a suitable role in trying to ease tensions between Japan and South Korea. (Newswires/Yonhap) Other News - UN report showed Japan illegally exported military and luxury items to North Korea. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS) - Co. is planning to boost investment in Israeli startups as it seeks to develop future mobility technologies. (Newswires)

Geopolitics - North Korea released full text of its new constitution in which it affirmed that North Korea is a nuclear state, according to South Korea press reports. (Newswires)

Other News - South Korea is considering reducing the extra-high rate levied on inheritance tax for top shareholders of large firms, while it was also reported that South Korea is considering levying capital gains tax for all shareholders in 5-10yrs. (Newswires)

ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include the New Zealand CPI and RBA Meeting Minutes
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump tweeted regarding China's slowing GDP in which he stated that many companies want to leave China for non-tariff countries and that China wishes it never broke the original deal, while he also reiterated that tariffs are paid by China not the US taxpayer. (Twitter)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he expects to have another call with his Chinese counterpart on trade this week and that there is a "good chance" he and USTR Lighthizer could visit China for further talks if progress is made. (Newswires)

  • Indian Trade Balance (USD)(Jun) -15.28B vs. Exp. -15.64B (Prev. -15.36B). (Newswires)
  • Indian Exports (USD)(Jun) 25.01B (Prev. 29.99B)
  • Indian Imports (USD)(Jun) 40.29B (Prev. 45.35B)
  • Indian WPI Inflation (Jun) Y/Y 2.02% vs. Exp. 2.35% (Prev. 2.45%)

 

UK/EU

UK trade with EU could be severely disrupted as leaked plans revealed that the UK is not prepared for a no-deal Brexit in October. (Business Insider)

EU Commission President nominee Von Der Leyen said she wants full flexibility of EU fiscal rules and is urging for a more growth friendly stance on fiscal policy, while she also commented that she would back an extension of Brexit talks if there is a good reason. (Newswires)

 

FX

Turkish Central Bank Governor Uysal said a framework will be used which maintains a reasonable real rate of return in regards to interest rates and that current economic developments open up room for a manoeuvre in monetary policy. Uysal also stated they will make a revision in the reserve tools in line with the global economic conditions and will take into account all of the macroeconomic indicators for monetary policy decisions. (Newswires) 

 

COMMODITIES

US Gulf of Mexico crude oil production cut by 69% (Prev. 73%) due to tropical storm Barry, while the NHC later stated that Barry has turned into a post-tropical cyclone and that flash flooding is still likely. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

EU's Foreign Policy Chief Mogherini said none of the signatories of the Iran deal have signalled an intention to invoke a dispute mechanism for the time being and that none of the parties believe Iran's breaches are significant non-compliance, while she added the Iran deal is not in good health but is still alive and that she cannot say if it is in its last hours. (Newswires)

UN said that all Yemeni warring sides have agreed on a mechanism and new measure to reinforce a ceasefire and de-escalation, which will be put in place as soon as possible. (Newswires)

 

US

US President Trump said if the USMCA deal does not pass congress he has a better plan and there were separate comments from White House Adviser Navarro that President Trump will sign an order today which looks to increase the domestic content threshold for domestic made iron and steel. (Newswires)

US President Trump is reportedly considering removing US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross following a stinging Supreme Court defeat on adding a citizenship question to the census according to multiple sources and some White House officials expect Ross to depart the administration possibly as soon as this summer. In other news, the White House formally nominated Mark Esper for US Defense Secretary. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he urged congress to raise the debt ceiling before the recess and does not expect the government to shutdown, while he added that productive discussions were held with congressional leaders on the debt ceiling. (Newswires)

US NY Fed Manufacturing (Jul) 4.3 vs. Exp. 2.0 (Prev. -8.6); largest monthly rise since June 2017. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Boeing (BA) shares moved lower on a WSJ report which suggested that the 737 MAX grounding could last into 2020. American Airlines (AAL) was under pressure after it extended flight cancellations related to the grounding into November, the fourth time the co. has extended such cancelations. Facebook (FB) also struggled, after reports the tech giant is close to reaching a settlement with the FTC, in which the co. would pay a USD 5bln fine. Gilead Sciences (GILD) shares opened higher on the news that the Biotech firm is to is to invest USD 5.1bln in Galapagos (GLPG), increasing its ownership stake in the co. to 22% from 12.3%, whilst also partnering with the Belgian-Dutch biotech firm to develop treatments over a ten-year period. Broadcom (AVGO) shares rose and Symantec’s (SYMC) fell after merger talks collapsed premarket. Callon Petroleum Co. (CPE) shares sunk on the news that the co. is to acquire Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO), whose share price shot higher. Amazon (AMZN) ticked higher as Prime Day kicked off, though there have been reports that its website is facing tech issues again. Nielsen Holdings (NLSN) was higher on vague takeover rumours that KKR (KKR) would potentially make a bid for the co. Notable stocks benefiting from positive upgrades; Hillenbrand (HI) upgraded at DA Davidson, Crocs (CROX) upgraded at Piper Jaffray. Notable stocks under pressure after negative broker moves; Teva Pharmaceuticals (TEVA) downgraded at Morgan Stanley, Tiffany & Co. (TIF) downgraded at Citi, Molson Coors Brewing Company (TAP), International Paper (IP) downgraded at Keybanc, Spirit Aerosystems (SPR) downgraded at Credit Suisse, Marriot International (MAR) downgraded at Longbow. S&P 500 0% AT 3014, NASDAQ-100 0.3% AT 7967, DOW JONES 0.1% AT 27359.

The T-plex saw some downward pressure following mixed Chinese data overnight however losses were pared back throughout the rest of the session, volume on Monday was weak ahead of key data points such as US retail sales on Tuesday and a slew of fed speak later in the week as we head towards the blackout period. Analysts noted some large block buys providing momentum, with 8.3k in TUU9 at 107.113 and 14.4k in TYU9 at 127’01. At settlement the curve had flattened, with the 30-year yield down by c. 2.5bps, and the 2s/30s contracted by just over 2bps. US T-note futures (U9) settled 2 ticks higher at 127-05+.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 15th July 2019: Trade subdued on the cusp of earnings season
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities flat/up, Treasuries flat/up, dollar up, crude lower.
  • REAR VIEW: China GDP growth meets consensus but strong IP; Mixed NY Fed Manufacturing survey; Citi disappoints on Q2 NIM; Mnuchin signals possible China visit
  • COMING UP: Data; UK Jobs Data, German ZEW US Import/Export Prices, Retail Sales, Industrial Production, Manufacturing Output & Business Inventories, Events; RBA Minutes, EC President Voting & Fed Discount Rate Minutes, Speakers; Fed’s Powell, Evans, Bowman, Bostic & Kaplan, BoE’s Carney & ECB’s de Galhau, Auctions; UK 2037 Gilts, Earnings; JP Morgan, Goldman Sachs, Wells Fargo, J&J, Kinder Morgan & Charles Schwab.

 

* MARKETS WRAP: Asian equities were supported by Chinese data overnight, which showed signs that the world's second largest economy was stabilising (growth in line, activity data saw a small upside surprise). The gains were maintained through the European session, but momentum faded during US hours; equity futures reversed course going into the US open, with activity subdued on the cusp of earnings season, whilst mixed Citi (C) Q2 earnings provided little in the way of positive stimulus. The lacklustre US session saw government debt yields lower and crude markets lower, in part due to the diminished risk appetite, as well as Gulf of Mexico weather related production disturbances not materialising as badly as originally feared.

* US EMPIRE STATE MANUFACTURING: US NY Fed Manufacturing data came in at 4.3, beating the expectations of 2.0, and rebounding from the weak June data of -8.6, resulting in the largest monthly gain since June 2017. Pantheon Macroeconomics notes that this was always likely due to the poor June figure, which was spurred by a combination of the increase in tariffs on Chinese Imports to 25% from 10%, and the week-long threat of tariffs on Mexican imports. Despite the rebound, Pantheon also notes that it has only half recovered the fall in June. The internals saw a different story to the rising headline number with the 'Fed' metrics eyed figures (prices paid and employment, both falling in July from 27.8 in June to 25.5 for prices paid and from -3.5 to a 42-month low of -9.6 for employment). New orders fell again in July but did rebound slightly to a -1.5 from -12 in June. Other analysts write that firms in the region are expecting figures to recover as the 6-month ahead new orders came in stronger at 35.4 from the 27.8 in June, just shy of the 2019 high of 35.7. The 6-month ahead figure for business conditions also saw an upward print of 30.8 above the prior 25.7.

* TRADE: US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he expects to have another call with his Chinese counterpart on trade later this week, before adding that there is a "good chance" he and USTR Lighthizer could visit China for further talks if progress is made. Separately, US President Trump said if the USMCA deal does not pass congress, then he has a better plan, although the details of this plan remain unclear.

* IRAN: Secretary of State Pompeo approved the granting of a visa to Iran's Foreign Minister Zarif, so he can attend a UN meeting in New York this week, although, Zarif's movements in the US have been severely curtailed, Pompeo added. Meanwhile, Iranian press on the weekend denied that a meeting between Zarif and Pompeo had been arranged, and a foreign ministry official said there were no negotiations going on between Iran and the US at any level. EU’s Foreign Policy Chief Mogherini seemingly presented Iran an olive branch; she said for the time being none of the signatories of the Iran deal have signalled an intention to invoke a dispute mechanism and that none of the parties believe Iran's breaches are significant non-compliance. Moreover, she went on to suggest that shareholders of the Iran Instex mechanism are discussing whether or not to include oil. Iran had earlier said it would stay committed to the nuclear deal providing other signatories stay committed and that they are expecting Europe to take operational steps to fulfil the deal, more specifically in oil. Elsewhere, in a move likely designed to strengthen ties between the two countries, a new Iranian visa waiver for Chinese tourists could be implemented as early as the end of this month; last week it was reported the US is weighing fresh sanctions against China for importing Iranian crude in violation of existing US sanctions.

* CHINA DATA: GDP growth in Q2 slowed in line with expectations to 6.2% Q/Q annualised, the slowest pace of growth since quarterly data was first published in 1992. The activity data released (industrial production, retail sales, fixed asset investment); analysts are taking the stabilisation as a sign that the government's fiscal stimulus efforts and the lower yuan have had the effect of partly shielding China's economy amid ongoing trade wars. However, some suggest that this still is not going to dissuade the PBOC from pursuing looser policy in the weeks/months ahead (some think days/weeks, though the consensus thinks the PBOC will await the outcome of July's Fed and ECB meetings first).

* US COMMERCE SECRETARY ROSS: US President Trump is reportedly considering removing US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross after a stinging Supreme Court defeat on adding a citizenship question to the census. Some White House officials now expect Ross to be the next Cabinet secretary to depart, possibly as soon as this summer.

* RBA MINS PREVIEW: In July, the RBA delivered a second consecutive rate cut of 25bps, taking its Cash Rate to 1.00%, and the minutes to the meeting are likely to give provide insight as to whether it is a 'two and done' as the central bank passes the baton of responsibility over to the fiscal authorities (recent tax changes could be the equivalent of a 50bps rate cut, analysts have suggested, easing the pressure on the RBA to cut rates further), or whether more easing remains on the cards. Some have warned that the minutes may strike a more dovish tone than the post-meeting statement, which contained little forward guidance. As other major central banks have, the RBA will likely caution on increasing global risks, soft inflation, and widening slack in the labour market. "Markets will likely continue to price in the risk of further easing, although we expect the RBA to sit on its hands in the coming months to assess the impact of 50bps of easing, near-term fiscal stimulus and recent APRA change to serviceability," RBC writes.

* HUAWEI: The Chinese tech giant is reportedly planning extensive layoffs in the US, as it continues to grapple with its US blacklisting; the WSJ reported that the layoffs are expected to impact Huawei subsidiary, Futurewei Technologies.

* JAPAN/SOUTH KOREA: The WTO has stepped into the latest escalation of trade tensions between South Korea and Japan, agreeing to formally discuss Seoul's grievances over Tokyo's restrictions against exports of semiconductor materials later this month, Nikkei reported. South Korea is likely to demand that Japan either fully justify the export curbs or withdraw them completely when the WTO's General Council convenes July 23rd/24th. Japan will likely respond by reiterating that the trade strictures are based on legitimate security concerns, Nikkei said, adding that the exchange is not expected to make much progress, and will more likely serve as a "venue for recruiting sympathizers" in the international arena, a diplomatic source said.

* BREXIT: Anti-Brexit campaign Gina Miller has threatened to sue any future government that prorogues parliament in an effort to engineer a hard exit from the EU.

* EUROPEAN TOP JOBS: Ahead of a vote this week, it appears Ursula Von Der Leyen has secured enough support to win a majority; Bloomberg News reported that over half of socialist MEPs will vote for her, and along with support from the centre-right MEPs, this should be enough for her to win the job to lead the European Commission. Von Der Leyen later commented that she wants full flexibility of EU fiscal rules and urging for a more growth friendly stance on fiscal policy, which could be a positive inclination for - fiscally constrained - Italy.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLED 2 TICKS HIGHER AT 127-05+. The T-plex saw some downward pressure following mixed Chinese data overnight however losses were pared back throughout the rest of the session, volume on Monday was weak ahead of key data points such as US retail sales on Tuesday and a slew of fed speak later in the week as we head towards the blackout period. Analysts noted some large block buys providing momentum, with 8.3k in TUU9 at 107.113 and 14.4k in TYU9 at 127’01. At settlement the curve had flattened, with the 30-year yield down by c. 2.5bps, and the 2s/30s contracted by just over 2bps.

* WTI FUTURES (Q9) SETTLE USD 0.63 LOWER AT USD 59.58/BBL; BRENT FUTURES (U9) SETTLE USD 0.24 LOWER AT USD 66.48/BBL: Crude futures had been drifting higher in the early session before reversing course into the US equity open amid fresh weather disruptions becoming a new factor in the market. “Tropical Depression” Barry continued to cause supply disruptions over the weekend in the Gulf of Mexico, where oil production had been curtailed by up to 73% over the weekend (69% according to the latest update); price gains have been limited with producers reportedly returning workforce personnel to platforms after Barry proved to be less damaging than previously expected. Citigroup’s energy analysts note that the impact has been limited on inland Louisiana refiners, which has seen downside in US product prices that is likely to be weighing on the major crude benchmarks; the bank’s running total has 5.4mln bbls of crude production lost through Sunday, “and still counting”. Participants have also been digesting China’s Q2 GDP growth, which continued to show a decelerating economy in the headline figure (6.2% YY), but June industrial production and retail sales did top estimates. The China demand concerns were somewhat overshadowed by its June crude throughput figures, which showed a rise of 7.7% YY to a record 13.07mln BPD, no-doubt assisted by the launch of two new 400k BPD refineries in May; Citi noted these figures fit with the narrative of stronger crude oil and the weakness in products. Looking ahead, the latest US energy inventory expectations see crude stocks drawing 3.4mln bbls, distillates building 0.4mln, and gasoline drawing 1.9mln bbls.

* S&P 500 0% AT 3014, NASDAQ-100 0.3% AT 7967, DOW JONES 0.1% AT 27359, S&P500 Sectors: Consumer Discretionary 0.3%, Consumer Staples 0.2%, Energy -0.9%, Financials -0.5%,Health Care 0.2%, Industrials -0.4%, Information Technology 0.3%, Materials 0.2%, Telecommunication Services 0.1%, Utilities 0.4%.

* EARNINGS: Citi kicked-off Q2 earnings seasons for financials with a solid beat on both top and bottom lines; Citi (and bank shares more broadly) initially jumped higher. However, as the market digested Citi’s NIM reading, which came in below expectations, gains were quickly reversed, and financials ended up an underperforming sector on the day, although Citigroup share price.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Boeing (BA) shares moved lower on a WSJ report which suggested that the 737 MAX grounding could last into 2020. American Airlines (AAL) was under pressure after it extended flight cancellations related to the grounding into November, the fourth time the co. has extended such cancelations. Facebook (FB) also struggled, after reports the tech giant is close to reaching a settlement with the FTC, in which the co. would pay a USD 5bln fine. Gilead Sciences (GILD) shares opened higher on the news that the Biotech firm is to is to invest USD 5.1bln in Galapagos (GLPG), increasing its ownership stake in the co. to 22% from 12.3%, whilst also partnering with the Belgian-Dutch biotech firm to develop treatments over a ten-year period. Broadcom (AVGO) shares rose and Symantec’s (SYMC) fell after merger talks collapsed premarket. Callon Petroleum Co. (CPE) shares sunk on the news that the co. is to acquire Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO), whose share price shot higher. Amazon (AMZN) ticked higher as Prime Day kicked off, though there have been reports that its website is facing tech issues again. Nielsen Holdings (NLSN) was higher on vague takeover rumours that KKR (KKR) would potentially make a bid for the co. Notable stocks benefiting from positive upgrades; Hillenbrand (HI) upgraded at DA Davidson, Crocs (CROX) upgraded at Piper Jaffray. Notable stocks under pressure after negative broker moves; Teva Pharmaceuticals (TEVA) downgraded at Morgan Stanley, Tiffany & Co. (TIF) downgraded at Citi, Molson Coors Brewing Company (TAP), International Paper (IP) downgraded at Keybanc, Spirit Aerosystems (SPR) downgraded at Credit Suisse, Marriot International (MAR) downgraded at Longbow.

* FX WRAP: Havens CHF and JPY were sold overnight, as activity data from China generally printed in line/slight beat vs expectations, helping to support risk, although Japanese players were away for a market holiday (108.50 is still the key resistance). Ahead of jobs data on Tuesday, GBP is lower, flirting with 1.25 again. The EUR was modestly weaker, while USD was modestly firmer; with some desks on the lookout for ECB sources stories this week to shape expectations ahead of the July meeting. Although the single currency is modestly lower on the day, desks have reasoned that a dovish Fed, Trump's weak USD preference, and optimism about global growth (in wake of better than expected Chinese data) should all provide support. CAD was initially firmer, benefitting from firmer risk sentiment and the BOC's neutral bias, which makes CAD attractive against USD (where the Fed is priced to cut rates this month), although finished the session marginally weaker vs the buck. Antipodeans, often seen as a proxy for Chinese growth, rallied on promising Chinese data (retail sales, industrial production and urban investment all beating expectations). EMFX was generally firmer on the day; ZAR consolidated around 13.90; despite former SA President Zuma appearing in court for a corruption enquiry and Eskom’s Treasurer resigning, and ahead of a potential SARB rate cut on Thursday. TRY held between 5.70-5.72 in spite of another Turkish sovereign ratings cut (at Fitch) and dovish sounding talk from the new CBRT head, with investors taking the postponement of last Friday’s US statement as a sign that any sanctions due to the Russian S-400 missile order may be less harsh than originally feared. BRL gradually weakened back to 3.7500, amidst reports that the Lower House of Congress may delay its Pension Reform Bill vote until after the Summer recess due to amendments that could cut the amount of savings from the overhaul.

Daily FX Wrap: All change for the Kiwi and Pound after Sunday’s Lords showdown
content:
NZD/GBP

In a strange quirk of fate and role reversal, the Kiwi and Pound are flanking the G10 ranks just a day after the World Cricket Cup final that saw England edge out New Zealand on a boundary count back. Nzd/Usd is consolidating comfortably above the 0.6700 handle, while Cable has slipped further from best levels back towards 1.2500 and only just held above Friday’s 1.2522 low as the Gbp/Nzd cross drops from just over 1.8800 to 1.8623 at one stage. Note, data could well provide the next major drivers for both currencies, with NZ Q2 CPI out later tonight and then UK labour and earnings scheduled on Tuesday.

AUD

The next best major and partly on a continuation of recalibrating and realigning positions to fit with the flip-flop in RBA vs Fed policy guidance/outlooks. However, Aud/Usd is also afloat within a 0.7038-09 range in wake of overnight Chinese macro releases showing ip and retail sales beats vs in line and multi-year slow GDP growth.

JPY/CHF/CAD/EUR

Still hugging tight lines vs the Usd as the DXY itself meanders in a narrow band just under the psychological 97.000 level, with the Yen tethered to 108.00 and awaiting the return of Japanese participants from their long holiday weekend (Marine Day). Meanwhile, soft Swiss producer and import prices have not hampered the Franc as Usd/Chf and Eur/Chf meander between 0.9818-54 and 1.1102-1.1067 respectively in contrast to the Loonie that lost some impetus following sub-forecast Canadian existing home sales, with Usd/Cad nearer the top of a 1.3042-21 band. The single currency stalled ahead of 1.1300 and major technical resistance above the big figure, and Eur/Usd is now testing chart support at 1.1262 (21 DMA).

EM 

Some contrasting and perhaps surprising performances across the region, as Usd/Try held around 5.7323-6978 in spite of another Turkish sovereign ratings cut and dovish sounding talk from new CBRT head with investors taking the postponement of last Friday’s US statement as a sign that any sanctions due to the Russian S-400 missile order may be less harsh than originally feared. Similarly, Usd/Zar reversed sharply from circa 13.9875 to 13.8590 even though former SA President Zuma appeared in court for a corruption enquiry and Eskom’s Treasurer resigned, but Usd/Brl gradually rallied from 3.7285 to 3.7531 amidst reports that the Lower House of Congress may delay its Pension Reform Bill vote until after the Summer recess due to amendments that could cut the amount of savings from the overhaul.

subject: BlackRock Commentary: The dovish pivot by global Central Banks should prolong the length of the economic cycle
content:
• On Central Banks; Blackrock expect low rates to persist, with the Fed poised to deliver an insurance rate cut soon and the ECB likely to provide additional stimulus by the end of October. As such, Blackrock think that the dovish pivot by global Central Banks should prolong the length of the economic cycle.
  • On trade tensions; Blackrock expect strategic tensions between the US/China to persist, regardless of the temporary trade truce. However, although trade tensions pose a risk to Q2 results, Blackrock expect company fundamentals to generally remain strong.
  • On EMs; Blackrock expect China’s growth to be broadly stable and prefer a selective approach to local-currency debt, favouring longer-term debt in Brazil, Mexico, India and Indonesia. They also note that consumption remains resilient in many EM economies, despite the global manufacturing slowdown.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 15th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Of note for automakers (GM, F); The Trump administration announced plans to issue final rules which will suspend an Obama era regulation that had more than doubled penalties for automakers who fail to meet fuel efficiency requirements.
  • Of note for steel names (X, AKS, AA, NUE); US President Trump is reportedly to sign an order which boosts the use of US steel for government orders.

DOW

  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) 737 MAX grounding is likely to stretch into 2020 due to the time it will take to fix flight-control software and complete other checks, reported the WSJ, which also noted that although the situation remains fluid, no firm timeline has been given, and Boeing still has to satisfy US regulators that it has addressed all outstanding safety questions. In related news, American Airlines (AAL) is extending daily flight cancellations related to the grounded 737 MAX into early November, a fourth time the airline has done so.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc (GOOG) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) – Facebook board member Peter Thiel has suggested that the FBI and CIA should investigate whether or not Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) has been infiltrated by Chinese intelligence.
  • Amazon.com Inc.’s (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) fourth annual Prime Day (this time a two-day event lasting until this Midnight Tuesday) has kicked off. The co., which sold over 100mln products during Prime Day in 2018 but did not give sales totals in dollars and is unlikely to this year. IgnitionOne estimates sales revenue to come in at USD 6.1bln, which would be a USD 2bln improvement on last year. Elsewhere, the ecommerce giant is reportedly planning the opening of a new warehouse in Germany this year, which would create roughly 2,800 permanent jobs. In other news related to Amazon’s operations in Germany; over 2000 workers across Amazon’s seven sites in the country have gone on strike over pay, lasting at least 2 days. Back across the pond, the ecommerce giant may be facing strikes during the Prime Day shopping event; a group of tech workers have expressed support for a planned strike by the co.’s warehouse workers in Shakopee, Minnesota.
  • Broadcom Inc. (AVGO) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) has raised USD 23bln in financing for its proposed acquisition of Symantec Corp. (SYMC) (Information Technology/Application Software), including USD 21bln towards the purchase of the co. and a further USD 2bln to cover costs associated with Symantec's convertible notes, other outstanding debt and associated fees, according to Dealreporter.
  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) is reportedly close to reaching a settlement with the FTC, in which the co. would pay a USD 5bln fine. Elsewhere, the co.’s Libra ambitions face a potential roadblock; House Democrats have drafted legislation that would prevent big tech companies from operating as financial institutions or issuing digital currencies.
  • Gilead Sciences (GILD) (Health Care/Biotechnology) is to invest USD 5.1bln in Galapagos (GLPG), increasing its ownership stake in the co. to 22% from 12.3%, whilst also partnering with the Belgian-Dutch biotech firm to develop treatments over a ten-year period. Gilead will be able to nominate two people on Galapagos' board.

S&P 500

  • Citigroup Inc. (C) (Financials/Diversified Banks) (USD) reported Q2 19 adj. EPS 1.83 (exp. 1.81), revenue 18.76bln (exp. 18.49bln), CET1 11.9% (unchanged from Q1), Fixed Income markets revenue 3.32bln (exp. 2.99bln), Equity markets revenue 0.79bln (exp. 0.82bln), NII 11.999bln (exp. 11.99bln), NIM 2.67% (exp. 2.72%) (lowest NIM in over a year).
  • Ford Motor (F) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) and United Auto Workers (UAW) will launch further talks on a four-year contract, with sticking points expected to be rising healthcare costs, job security and the use of temporary workers. Ford, and other automakers, are under pressure from falling vehicle sales, whilst the UAW face their own problems relating to a wide-ranging corruption probe.
  • General Electric (GE) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) was downgraded to Neutral from Buy at UBS; analyst Damian Karas commented that a "notable" decline in interest rates and continued weakness in the power market combine toward more balance between possible upside and downside for the co.
  • Molson Coors Brewing Company (TAP) (Consumer Staples/Brewers) has been downgraded to Underperform from Buy and had its PT cut to USD 50 from USD 70 at BAML. The bank site concerns that the brewer may have to increase spending to stabilise market share for some of its core brands.
  • Tiffany & Co. (TIF) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel, Accessories & Luxury Goods) has been downgraded to Neutral from Buy at Citi; analyst Paul Lejuez said that the company's guidance hopes for a "big improvement" in H2 19 results versus H1 19, and there is significant risk that the second half turnaround "does not go according to plan”.

OTHER

  • Callon Petroleum (CPE) (Energy/Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels) is set to acquire Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO) (Energy/Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels) in an all stock deal valued at USD 3.2bln. Carrizo shareholders will receive a fixed exchange ratio of 2.05 Callon shares for each share of Carrizo common stock representing USD 13.12 per Carrizo share (based on Callon's closing price on 12 July) and a premium of 24% on Carrizo's closing price on 12 July.
  • Slack Technologies (WORK) (Information Technology/Software) was initiated at Overweight at Barlcays; the bank site optimism regarding the co.’s revenue growth prospects, despite a “demanding valuation”.
  • Teva (TEVA) (Health care/Pharmaceuticals) were downgraded to Underweight from Neutral Weight at Morgan Stanley; analyst David Risinger siting "underappreciated" risks from worse than expected buying group pressure, increasing competition and opioid litigation, which is "just getting started" with thousands of lawsuits having been filed.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 15th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices [Euro Stoxx 50 U/C] have been choppy throughout the session but overall are little changed on the day
  • US President Trump is reportedly considering removing US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, separate reports indicate that US firms may be able to restart Huawei purchases in the next 2-4 weeks
  • In FX, the USD is generally soft this far with most G10 counterparts little changed though antipodeans outperform
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, New York Fed Manufacturing, New Zealand CPI. Fed’s Williams and earnings from Citigroup

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed as the region digested a slew of tier-1 Chinese data and with the absence of Japanese participants adding to the initial lull. ASX 200 (-0.6%) was negative with the downside led by underperformance in tech and telecoms, while financials also weighed on the index with AMP Capital shares down around 15% after it noted the unlikelihood it will proceed with its life insurance unit sale due to opposition by the RBNZ. Conversely, Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) were pressured at the open after the recent mixed lending and trade data from China, while participants were also cautious as they awaited more tier-1 releases from the world’s 2nd largest economy including Chinese GDP, Industrial Production and Retail Sales. The data then proved to be better than expected as most of the figures topped estimates which inspired a recovery in stocks, although still showed China’s economic growth slipped to 6.2% Y/Y as expected which was the slowest pace since 1992.

PBoC skipped open market operations but injected CNY 200bln via 1yr MLF at rate kept at 3.3%, while it implemented the 3rd phase of RRR cuts for county-level rural commercial banks that would release long-term funds of about CNY 100bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8677 (Prev. 6.8662)

Huawei is said to plan deep job cuts in US as it struggles with the US blacklisting, while there were separate reports that US firms may get the go ahead to restart new sales to Huawei in the next 2-4 weeks. (WSJ/Newswires)

China detained another Canadian citizen which is said to add to the high tensions between the two countries. (NYT)

Chinese GDP (Q2) Q/Q 1.6% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.4%). (Newswires) Chinese GDP (Q2) Y/Y 6.2% vs. Exp. 6.2% (Prev. 6.4%); slowest pace of growth since 1992. Chinese Industrial Production (Jun) Y/Y 6.3% vs. Exp. 5.2% (Prev. 5.0%) Chinese Retail Sales (Jun) Y/Y 9.8% vs. Exp. 8.3% (Prev. 8.6%) Chinese China House Prices (Jun) Y/Y 10.3% (Prev. 10.7%)

US

US President Trump will not impose uranium quotas despite assessment by the Commerce Department that US use of foreign uranium raises security concerns. (Newswires)

US President Trump is reportedly considering removing US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, according to NBC citing sources. (NBC)

- After a stinging Supreme Court defeat on adding a citizenship question to the census, according to multiple people familiar with the conversations

- Some White House officials expect Ross to be the next Cabinet secretary to depart, possibly as soon as this summer

UK/EU

UK PM candidate Boris Johnson will seek a UK trade deal with US in first move if he becomes PM. In related news, there were reports that US President Trump’s negotiators signalled that hopes of a post-Brexit trade deal with the US rest on the willingness of the next PM to fall in line with tough American policies against Huawei. (Newswires/Times/Telegraph)

A hard Brexit could be made more likely because European Union leaders have failed to grasp the firming of opinion in Britain, Latvia’s foreign minister has warned. (Telegraph)

Conservative candidate Hunt has declared that he would take on the role of Brexit Secretary himself because it is “too big” a responsibility not to be carried out by the prime minister. (Telegraph)

UK Chancellor Hammond has vowed to oppose a no-deal Brexit from the back benches in a valedictory speech to civil servants last week, according to The Times. (Times)

Direct rule will be implemented in Northern Ireland within the next three months to see through Brexit, ministers believe. (Times)

UK Rightmove House Prices (Jul) M/M -0.2% (Prev. 0.3%). (Newswires) UK Rightmove House Prices (Jul) Y/Y -0.2% (Prev. 0.0%)

German Economy Ministry says that domestic industrial activity remains sluggish with headwinds from foreign demand still being felt. (Newswires)

- Current data suggests a weak general economic trend in Q2 but forces of economic upswing could become more prominent thereafter if the external environment settles

GEOPOLITICS

Iran President Rouhani said Iran is ready and willing to hold talks if US sanctions are lifted and US returns to the 2015 nuclear deal, while there were separate comments from Iran Foreign Minister Zarif that Iran will continue with its oil exports no matter what the conditions. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European indices have drifted lower in recent trade, but are largely unchanged [Eurostoxx 50 U/C] following on from a mixed Asia-Pac trade as volumes were mired amid the absence of Japan. Sectors are also little inspired, albeit material names benefiting marginally from the boost in base metal prices post-Chinese data. Meanwhile, movers include the likes of Antofagasta (+4.0%) after the Co’s JV with Barrick Gold was awarded USD 5.84bln in damages from a legal dispute with the Pakistani government. Elsewhere, AB InBev (-2.0%) shares declined after the Co. back-tracked on its Hong Kong IPO plans due to little demand from long-term investors, the IPO was meant aid the Co. with its USD 100bln debt pile. Airbus (+0.6%) shares rose in early trade amid a weekend WSJ article which highlighted Boeing’s 737 Max is likely to be grounded until January next year as the jet is yet to satisfy all safety requirements, according to union leaders and officials. Finally, analysts at JPM have raised their 12-month S&P 500 price target to 3200 (Prev. 3000) citing factors including synchronised easing of global central banks, attractive relative valuation, intracycle profit recovering by year-end and a record share buyback to buoy equity demand; for reference, the S&P closed at a record 3013 on Friday. The analysts also expect a partial US-Sino trade deal heading into the US election year, although this has been caveated as their largest single downside risk to the view.

Citigroup (C) – are due to report earnings at 13:00 BST today, in terms of focus some are highlighting that management guidance around NII is key, rather than the headline prints (EPS Exp. USD 1.81, revenue Exp. USD 18.49bln); emphasis has been placed on the potential need for NII to be guided lower. (Newswires)

FX

NZD/AUD - The Antipodean Dollars continue to outperform, and the latest advances have been made with the aid of better than expected Chinese data in the form of ip and retail sales. However, with GDP in line with consensus and slowing to a 27 year low, it is the Kiwi rather than Aussie that has really extended gains from last week to a 0.6725 high vs its US counterpart and towards 1.0450 in cross terms as Aud/Usd stalls at 0.7035. Note also, Westpac sees more upside for Nzd/Usd in the short term based on the Fed’s dovish tilt, but then a reversal through 0.6600 next month assuming the RBNZ eases again. More immediately, NZ inflation for Q2 looms and the forecast is for firmer CPI prints.

CHF/EUR/JPY/CAD - All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, but with the Franc also getting a bullish nod via a bank trade recommendation as MS favours going short of Usd/Chf at current levels circa 0.9835 for 0.9730 with a 0.9980 stop, while Eur/Chf hovers closer to the base of a 1.1100-1.1085 range and shrugs off weak Swiss producer/import prices. Meanwhile, the single currency remains trapped in a tight range inside 1.1250-1.1300 vs the Buck and flanked by key chart support and resistance, like the 100 DMA at 1.1255, a 50% Fib at 1.1303 and the 200 DMA at 1.1323. Elsewhere, the Yen is pivoting 108.00 in an equally tight range and with trade/interest hampered by Japan’s Marine Day market holiday, but the Loonie is consolidating recent gains between 1.3042-22 after last Wednesday’s relatively hawkish or neutral BoC hold.

GBP - In stark contrast to yesterday’s Lords result, the Pound is lagging behind G10 peers, and especially the Kiwi. Cable is only just holding 1.2550 after another fade ahead of 1.2600 even though the Dollar is generally soft and the DXY is depressed below 97.000, with the ongoing UK political void weighing on sentiment and Brexit still up in the air as a result.

EM - The Lira is holding up quite well in the face of another Turkish ratings downgrade (1 peg by Fitch to BB-, outlook negative) with Usd/Try meandering between 5.7070-7325 vs a peak of 5.7800 late last Friday when a White House statement about Turkey’s S-400 missile system purchase from Russia was unexpectedly shelved amidst speculation that US President Trump may err on the side of lenience when it comes to any sanctions. Conversely, the Real may come under pressure and Usd/Brl rally from 3.7400 on the back of reports Brazil’s lower house could delay a vote on pension reforms until August (ie after this Friday’s recess) due to proposed amendments that could diminish the financial savings from the new package.

Turkish President Erdogan reportedly said that Turkey will make serious cuts to interest rates, according to Haberturk. And that Turkey is aiming to reduce inflation to a single digit figure by the years end. (Newswires) For reference the next CBRT decision is July 25th.

US President Trump’s team has reportedly agreed on a package of sanctions to be placed on Turkey in response to their reception of the S-400 Russian missile system; with the source stating this is to be announced later in the week. (Newswires)

Brazil's lower house of Congress may not vote on the pension reform bill until next month as tough negotiations over amendments delayed the process and reduced savings derived from the overhaul. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME 

Bunds and Eurozone peers continue to lead the recovery from recent lows, and the former reclaimed 172.00 before losing momentum having bounced further from the 171.49 overnight Eurex low. Market contacts point out that this represented a Fib retracement and the inference is that tech traders/jobbers may have been behind the subsequent rebound, with stops perhaps tripped when near term resistance was breached around 171.79. However, a downturn in EU stocks could be another factor while the sheer scale and speed of the fall in debt/back-up in yields is likely to have contributed or at least added impetus. However, the core German bond faces another chart hurdle around 172.12 and Gilts at 130.89 vs 172.06 and 130.72 at best thus far, while USTs remain below par and the back end is still underperforming ahead of the first of the big bank earnings, Empire State manufacturing and Fed’s Williams.

COMMODITIES

Little to report on the energy front, although WTI and Brent futures remain choppy within a relatively narrow intraday band thus far. The former currently hovers just above the 60/bbl mark whilst the latter remains afloat closer to the 67/bbl, as the benchmarks largely reflect market sentiment in the absence of fresh catalysts. Elsewhere, Hurricane Barry has abated to a tropical depression, with eyes now on any refineries coming back online after the Gulf’s crude output was cut by 70% on Friday amid storm preparations. ING notes that output in the Gulf is likely to return to normal levels over the coming days. Meanwhile, gold prices are little changed amid a steady USD and base metals were bolstered by the mostly upbeat Chinese data overnight. As such copper has reclaimed 2.7/lb to the upside while nickel surged in excess of 3.0% deriving additional strength from supply woes.

BSEE said Gulf of Mexico crude output was cut by 70% on Friday and natural gas output was reduced by 56% due to storm preparations, while the NHC stated on Sunday that Barry weakened to a tropical depression over north-western Louisiana and that life-threatening flooding rains will continue into Monday. (Newswires)

Iraq Southern oil exports averaged 3.42mln BPD so far in July (vs. 3.39mln BPD in June), according to officials. (Newswires)

Kazakhstan oil and condensate production +15.5% M/M to 7.75mln BPD. (Newswires)

subject: JP Morgan raise their 12-month price target for the S&P 500 to 3200 from 3000
content:
JP Morgan cites the following reasons 

  1. 1) Synchronized global monetary easing 
  2. 2) Expectation of a partial trade deal as the US election year approaches (largest single downside risk to their view) 
  3. 3) Year-end to see an intra-cycle profit recovery with negative revisions likely to peak during Q2 earnings season
  4. 4) Attractive relative valuation
  5. 5) Average equity positioning and still negative investor sentiment
  6. 6) Record share buybacks continue to support steady demand for equities 
  7.

subject: UK debt and STIR futures glean some encouragement from resilience elsewhere
content: A timely if still not firm or assured rebound in Bunds (to 171.77 before fading) has helped Gilts regain composure after a soft return to Liffe with the latter now holding an underlying bid between 130.35-52 parameters vs last Friday’s 130.41 close. However, trade is tentative and the overall tone not very convincing as debt markets continue to ‘correct’ or reverse from early July record highs and eye a firmer tone in EU equities in wake of several stronger than expected Chinese data points overnight. Back to Liffe, Short Sterling contracts are flitting either side of par within -1/+1 tick confines ahead of a run of primary domestic releases kicking off from Tuesday with jobs and earnings, followed by 2037 DMO supply and a speech from BoE Governor Carney.

Lufthansa (LHA GY) – Co’s Chief Executive reportedly expects passenger numbers to rise by 4% this year. (Newswires)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – Audi’s CEO is reportedly seeking greater synergies with the Co. in order to pursue higher earnings. (Newswires)

Peugeot (UG FP) – H1 sales volume fell 12.8% to 1.9mln light vehicles. H1 China sales fell 60.6%. (Newswires) 

GlaxoSmithKline (GSK LN) – Co. announced positive results in Phase III prima study of Zejula, which met primary endpoints. (Newswires) 

Sports Direct (SPD LN) – Co. has delayed its results until beyond 18th July due to complexities of integration into company of House of Fraser business. (Newswires)

Antofagasta (ANTO LN) – Tribunal of the World Banks International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes has awarded USD 5.84bln in damages to Tethyan Copper, which is a JV between the Co. and Barrick Gold. This award is not expected to be recognised in the Co’s financial statements until the date in which it is received. (Newswires)

Renault (RNO FP) – Co. has given French Prosecutors the results of an audit into the Co’s joint finances with Nissan. (Newswires)

subject: Bunds: mostly downside trade after fleeting or false opening mark-up
content: The 10 year German benchmark has been unable (so far) to make any further headway following a modestly firmer start to the new week as offers immediately pushed prices back down from an initial 171.74 print to a 171.49 low. However, after last week’s abrupt and hefty correction in global bonds the core Eurozone debt future is trying to form a base and has edged up above parity again (171.75 vs the previous 171.68 close) even though US Treasuries remain weak and steeper. Indeed, some further consolidation and 2-way trade would not be surprising given the fact that yields have rebounded significantly and the ECB is expected to turn more dovish again next week. Moreover, -25 bp may well prove as sticky on the upside as the -40 bp level did on the way down, especially if the depo rate is shaved again in due course.

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

15th July 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed as the region digested a slew of tier-1 Chinese data and with the absence of Japanese participants adding to the initial lull. ASX 200 (-0.4%) was negative with the downside led by underperformance in tech and telecoms, while financials also weighed on the index with AMP Capital shares down around 15% after it noted the unlikelihood it will proceed with its life insurance unit sale due to opposition by the RBNZ. Conversely, Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) were pressured at the open after the recent mixed lending and trade data from China, while participants were also cautious as they awaited more tier-1 releases from the world’s 2nd largest economy including Chinese GDP, Industrial Production and Retail Sales. The data then proved to be better than expected as most of the figures topped estimates which inspired a recovery in stocks, although still showed China’s economic growth slipped to 6.2% Y/Y as expected which was the slowest pace since 1992.

FTSE 100

GlaxoSmithKline (GSK LN) – Co. is to appoint Jonathan Symonds as its new chairman to oversee Co’s breakup. (FT)

Persimmon (PSN LN) – Co. has apologised “without reservation” after a Dispatches documentary revealed Co.’s quality control and safety issues. (Telegraph)

Balfour Beatty (BBY LN) – Co. has launched an investigation into whether its US military business previously falsified records, allegations pursued by US Democratic Senator Elizabeth Warren. (FT) 

Travis Perkins (TPK LN) – Co. is reportedly planning to accelerate the sale of its Wickes division, which could be worth around GBP 500mln. (Times)

Thomas Cook (TCG LN) – Co’s UK departures were delayed by an average of 23 minutes last year, according to PA news agency analysing Civil Aviation Authority data. (BBC) Furthermore, S&P cut rating to CC from CCC+; outlook negative. (Newswires)

Vodafone (VOD LN) – Co. has agreed with Portugal’s dstelecom on terms for a new fiber optic network which will allow both operations to extend the number of home in reach. (negocios)

Housing names - UK Rightmove House Prices (Jul) M/M -0.2% (Prev. 0.3%); Y/Y -0.2% (Prev. 0.0%). (Newswires)

Gambling names – A new legal duty of care being considered by a committee could see betting shops with more than one member of staff overlooking addicted gamblers. (Telegraph)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

DAX

BASF (BAS GY) – Moody’s has placed Co. on review for a potential downgrade. (Newswires)

Deutsche Boerse (DB1 GY) – European Energy Exchange CEO expects high growth rate to continue. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Evotec (EVT GY) – Co. has acquired assets from Ncardia which includes IP portfolio, IPSC-based cellular products and a stem cell biology team. (Newswires) Co. shares are seen opening +1.3%.

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – Boeing’s (BA) 737 Max is likely to be grounded until January next year as the jet is yet to satisfy all safety requirements, according to union leaders and officials. (WSJ/ Times)

SocGen (GLE FP) – Co. is said to cut jobs at its London office as part of its CEO’s revamp. Co. also aims to cut risk-weighted assets by EUR 10bln. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

DANONE (BN FP) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM UNDERPERFORM AT CREDIT SUISSE

PAN EUROPE

AB InBev (ABI BB) – Co. has scrapped plans for its Budweiser Hong Kong IPO after it did not secure enough demand from long-term investors and amid “several factors, including the prevailing market conditions”. The IPO was meant to help the Co. reduce its USD 100bln debt. (Telegraph) 

Vivendi (VIV FP)/ Mediaset (MS IM) – An Italian law that forced Vivendi to forfeit most of its voting rights in Mediaset may not be complying with EU rules, according to documents. (Newswires)

TomTom (TOM2 NA) – Galileo, Europe’s satellite navigation system, has been offline since Friday morning meaning systems will relying on the data from GPS, Glonass or Beidou networks. (BBC)

Recordati (REC IM) – Co. is to acquire rights to Signifor for USD 390mln from Novartis (NOVN SW). (Newswires)

Atlantia (ATL IM) – Co. alongside three potential investors have submitted expressions of interest to join a consortium for the rescue of Alitalia., according to a government minister. (Newswires)

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – Open Fiber’s Chief Executive reportedly stated that a merger of the Co. and Open Fiber’s assets would be a deal to pursue if it increased fibre coverage and innovation. (Newswires)

Poste Italiane (PST IM) – Co. intends to become Italy’s largest parcel delivery name in e-commerce by 2022, which the Co’s CEO says will be due to a deal signed with Amazon (AMZN) last year., according to La Repubblica. (Newswires)

Mediobanca (MB IM) – Co. may be interest in purchasing shares in FinecoBank (FBK IM). (Newswires)

Salini Impregilo (SAL IM) – Co. are expected to approve a takeover bid for Astaldi (AST IM) on Monday. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SMI

LafargeHolcim (LHN SW) – Co. have reached an agreement with Oresa regarding the acquisition of Somaco, a concrete producer. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 15th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded mixed as the region digested a slew of tier-1 Chinese data and with the absence of Japanese participants adding to the initial lull
  • Chinese data proved to be mostly better than forecast, although showed China’s economic growth slipped to 6.2% Y/Y as expected
  • DXY was relatively stable with marginal gains seen as it briefly attempted to nurse some of last week’s losses, while price action for its major counterparts was mixed
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US NY Fed Manufacturing, NZ CPI, Fed’s Williams

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed as the region digested a slew of tier-1 Chinese data and with the absence of Japanese participants adding to the initial lull. ASX 200 (-0.4%) was negative with the downside led by underperformance in tech and telecoms, while financials also weighed on the index with AMP Capital shares down around 15% after it noted the unlikelihood it will proceed with its life insurance unit sale due to opposition by the RBNZ. Conversely, Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) were pressured at the open after the recent mixed lending and trade data from China, while participants were also cautious as they awaited more tier-1 releases from the world’s 2nd largest economy including Chinese GDP, Industrial Production and Retail Sales. The data then proved to be better than expected as most of the figures topped estimates which inspired a recovery in stocks, although still showed China’s economic growth slipped to 6.2% Y/Y as expected which was the slowest pace since 1992.

PBoC skipped open market operations but injected CNY 200bln via 1yr MLF at rate kept at 3.3%, while it implemented the 3rd phase of RRR cuts for county-level rural commercial banks that would release long-term funds of about CNY 100bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8677 (Prev. 6.8662)

Huawei is said to plan deep job cuts in US as it struggles with the US blacklisting, while there were separate reports that US firms may get the go ahead to restart new sales to Huawei in the next 2-4 weeks. (WSJ/Newswires)

China detained another Canadian citizen which is said to add to the high tensions between the two countries. (NYT)

Chinese GDP (Q2) Q/Q 1.6% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.4%). (Newswires) Chinese GDP (Q2) Y/Y 6.2% vs. Exp. 6.2% (Prev. 6.4%); slowest pace of growth since 1992. Chinese Industrial Production (Jun) Y/Y 6.3% vs. Exp. 5.2% (Prev. 5.0%) Chinese Retail Sales (Jun) Y/Y 9.8% vs. Exp. 8.3% (Prev. 8.6%) Chinese China House Prices (Jun) Y/Y 10.3% (Prev. 10.7%)

UK/EU

UK PM candidate Boris Johnson will seek a UK trade deal with US in first move if he becomes PM. In related news, there were reports that US President Trump’s negotiators signalled that hopes of a post-Brexit trade deal with the US rest on the willingness of the next PM to fall in line with tough American policies against Huawei. (Newswires/Times/Telegraph)

A hard Brexit could be made more likely because European Union leaders have failed to grasp the firming of opinion in Britain, Latvia’s foreign minister has warned. (Telegraph)

Conservative candidate Hunt has declared that he would take on the role of Brexit Secretary himself because it is “too big” a responsibility not to be carried out by the prime minister. (Telegraph)

UK Chancellor Hammond has vowed to oppose a no-deal Brexit from the back benches in a valedictory speech to civil servants last week, according to The Times. (Times)

Direct rule will be implemented in Northern Ireland within the next three months to see through Brexit, ministers believe. (Times)

UK Rightmove House Prices (Jul) M/M -0.2% (Prev. 0.3%). (Newswires) UK Rightmove House Prices (Jul) Y/Y -0.2% (Prev. 0.0%)

 

FX

DXY was relatively stable with marginal gains seen as it briefly attempted to nurse some of last week’s losses, while price action for its major counterparts were mixed with EUR/USD and GBP/USD little-changed amid a lack of pertinent news flow for the pairs over the weekend. Conversely, antipodeans benefitted from the latest Chinese data in which AUD/USD broke through last week’s resistance and NZD/USD gained a footing above 0.6700, while there was also a note from Westpac on NZD/USD which it sees appreciating in the next few weeks if the Fed provides dovish guidance, before dropping to below 0.6600 in August should the RBNZ reduce rates again. Elsewhere, USD/JPY just about reclaimed the 108.00 handle and JPY-crosses were also lifted in the aftermath of the Chinese data but with upside restricted due to absence of Tokyo participants.

Brazil's lower house of Congress may not vote on the pension reform bill until next month as tough negotiations over amendments delayed the process and reduced savings derived from the overhaul. (Newswires)

 

Turkish President Erdogan reportedly said that Turkey will make serious cuts to interest rates, according to Haberturk. And that Turkey is aiming to reduce inflation to a single digit figure by the years end. (Newswires) For reference the next CBRT decision is July 25th.

US President Trump’s team has reportedly agreed on a package of sanctions to be placed on Turkey in response to their reception of the S-400 Russian missile system; with the source stating this is to be announced later in the week. (Newswires)

Fitch downgraded Turkey to 'BB-'; Outlook Negative. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were varied and largely reflected the mixed trading session in which WTI crude futures briefly slipped below the USD 60.00/bbl level as Asia markets began the trading day with losses across the board, but later rebounded off lows as sentiment eventually improved post-China data. In terms of the latest developments regarding the Gulf of Mexico disruption, crude output was said to have been cut by 70% on Friday and Barry has since been downgraded to a tropical depression, although several tornado warnings have been issued with a high risk of flooding due to heavy rain. Elsewhere, gold marginally weakened amid a steady greenback and as the risk tone began to pick up, while copper outperformed helped by the China data and as it broke through prior resistance at USD 2.70/lb.

 

US Baker Hughes Rig Count (12 July): Oil rigs -4 at 784, NatGas rigs -2 at 172, total rigs -5 at 958 rigs. (Newswires)

 

BSEE said Gulf of Mexico crude output was cut by 70% on Friday and natural gas output was reduced by 56% due to storm preparations, while the NHC stated on Sunday that Barry weakened to a tropical depression over north-western Louisiana and that life-threatening flooding rains will continue into Monday. (Newswires) 

GEOPOLITICS

 

Iran President Rouhani said Iran is ready and willing to hold talks if US sanctions are lifted and US returns to the 2015 nuclear deal, while there were separate comments from Iran Foreign Minister Zarif that Iran will continue with its oil exports no matter what the conditions. (Newswires)

South Korea official voiced uncertainty over US-North Korea talks this month and said the US appears to be waiting for a response from North Korea. (Yonhap)

US

A lacklustre session saw Treasury yields come in by around a basis point or so. Fed speak (Evans, Kashkari, Brainard) was generally positive for the complex given the dovish rhetoric. The yield curve steepened slightly. Major curve spreads were mixed, but relatively unchanged. US T-note futures (U9) settled 4 ticks higher at 127-03+.

US President Trump will not impose uranium quotas despite assessment by the Commerce Department that US use of foreign uranium raises security concerns. (Newswires)

Fed's Barkin (Non-Voter, Hawk) said the fact that inflation is low is a victory is not a defeat and that consumer spending is incredibly strong. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia eventually traded mixed as the region digests recent Chinese data and with Japan shut for holiday
content:
Asia equity markets trade mixed as the region fails to take impetus from the fresh record highs made on Wall St last Friday, as the region digests the recent slew of tier-1 Chinese data releases and with the absence of Japanese participants adding to the lull. ASX 200 (-0.4%) is negative with the downside led by underperformance in tech and telecoms, while financials also weigh on the index with AMP Capital shares down around 14% after it noted the unlikelihood it will proceed with its life insurance unit sale due to opposition by the RBNZ. Conversely, Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) were pressured at the open after the recent mixed lending and trade data from China, with participants also cautious as they awaited more tier-1 releases from the world’s 2nd largest economy. Today’s economic updates then proved to be better than expected as most of the figures for Chinese GDP, Industrial Production and Retail Sales topped estimates which lifted stocks off their lows, although still showed China’s economic growth slipped to 6.2% Y/Y as expected to its slowest pace since 1992.

In FX markets, the DXY is relatively stable with marginal gains seen as it makes its way back towards the 97.00 level, while price action for its major counterparts are mixed with EUR/USD and GBP/USD little-changed amid a lack of pertinent news flow for the pairs over the weekend. Conversely, antipodeans benefitted from the latest Chinese data which helped AUD/USD break through last week’s resistance and with NZD/USD gaining a footing above 0.6700, while there was also a note from Westpac on NZD/USD which it sees appreciating in the next few weeks if the Fed provides dovish guidance, before dropping to below 0.6600 in August should the RBNZ reduce rates again. Elsewhere, USD/JPY just about reclaimed the 108.00 handle and JPY-crosses were also lifted in the aftermath of the Chinese data but with upside restricted due to absence of Tokyo participants and the cautious risk tone.

Huawei

Protests

Dozens of protesters were arrested and multiple injuries reported during weekend protests calling for full withdrawal of the extradition bill. (Newswires)

 

Trade

US President Trump repeated that countries have been ripping US off for years and that tariffs are a great negotiating tool and revenue producer, while he also stated that the biggest parts of Mexico and China trade deals have not yet been revealed. Furthermore, Trump accused China of devaluing its currency, playing around with monetary policy and subsidizing its companies to lessen effect of tariffs, while he also repeated that tariffs are so far having little effect to consumers. (Newswires)

White House Trade Adviser Navarro said we are in a 'quiet period' regarding US-China talks. (Newswires)

 

Other News

PBoC official said they will further reduce real interest rates for small firms and that China will take macro-prudential measures when necessary to keep CNY basically stable. (Newswires)

Chinese Foreign Minister Yi urged the US 'not to play with fire' on the question of Taiwan, while it was also reported that China are to place sanctions on US firms involved in arms sales to Taiwan. (Newswires)

China detained another Canadian citizen which is said to add to the high tensions between the two countries. (NYT)
